Award.AwardTitle: Micro-Macro Decomposition Numerical Schemes for Multiscale Simulation of Plasma
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plasma physics is the study of the dynamics of ionized gases. Because plasma, often referred to as the fourth state of matter, is the most abundant form of ordinary matter in the universe, there exist many important application problems for which an understanding of the plasma dynamics is critical. Some examples of these applications include understanding the dynamics of stars, the affect of the solar wind on the Earth's magnetosphere, the dynamics of magnetically confined fusion devices, and the dynamics of laser-plasma devices that could be used in medical imaging applications. The objective of this research is to develop highly accurate and efficient computational tools for simulating the dynamics of the electrons (negatively charged particles) and the ions (positively charged particles) that constitute the plasma of interest. This research aims to develop novel computational techniques based on novel multiscale methods that divide the underlying equations into macroscopic (large scale phenomena) and microscopic (small scale phenomena), and couple these scales in some appropriate manner. These methods will be implemented in computer code that will take advantage of modern parallel computer architectures. The resulting methods and codes will be used to simulate various application problems in order to verify and validate the approach.

The primary objective of this research is to develop accurate and efficient computational methods for solving nonlinear differential equations used to model plasma dynamics. The goal is to solve a class of multiscale models of plasma using a novel micro-macro decomposition approach. The idea behind the micro-macro decomposition is to start with a general enough model that contains the coupled dynamics of macroscopic and microscopic phenomena, to then write this model into two parts with appropriate coupling terms, and finally to apply potentially different numerical techniques to each part in order to optimize efficiency. The specific schemes that will be used in this research are based on high-order discontinuous Galerkin finite element methods with novel time-stepping strategies to achieve computational efficiency. This research will develop new computational tools for simulating plasma dynamics. In particular, new micro-macro decomposition techniques will be designed and implemented that allow for the efficient numerical solution of multi-species plasma systems. New strategies will be developed to adaptively turn on and off the microscopic solvers. As part of the research project, novel computational methods and software will be produced that in the future could be applied to a wide range of both laboratory and astrophysical plasma problems. The software developed will be made freely available on the web as part of the DoGPack software project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to study and develop mathematical models and associated computational methods for simulating kinetic phenomena as they arise in various application problems such as gas dynamics, plasma physics, and neutron transport. The key challenge is to make the computational tools for solving kinetic models efficient for realistic problems. The difficulty lies in the fact that kinetic models are either integral or partial differential equations defined on a high-dimensional phase-space. Furthermore, kinetic equations are multiscale; they describe phenomena that span many orders of magnitude in both spatial and temporal scales, which makes the equations stiff and difficult to solve computationally.

The research efforts resulted in several journal publications. Some key findings from these journal articles are summarized below.

* Moment-closure techniques for kinetic equations: The PI, students, and collaborators developed novel moment-closure techniques to arrive at improved fluid approximations of kinetic models. An important aspect of this research has been the development of numerical methods that preserve important invariants of the fluid models.

* Development of novel high-order discontinuous Galerkin methods with improved linear stability properties: An important tool in solving both fluid and kinetic models is high-order numerical methods based on explicit time-stepping schemes. One critical challenge, however, is that high-order schemes generally have poor linear stability properties. In this sub-project, the PI, students, and collaborators developed new time-stepping approaches based on regionally-implicit time-stepping schemes. These have the computational complexity of explicit schemes but allow for significantly improved linear stability properties.

* Development of novel moment-closures and numerical methods for linear kinetic transport models: Linear kinetic models arise in many applications, including in including remote sensing, glass manufacturing, and combustion. These models require accurate and efficient approximation techniques that can resolve enough of the physically important phase space and that can handle the vast differences in spatial and temporal scales that may arise. The PI, students, and collaborators considered two parallel challenges: (1) developing improved moment closure approximations and (2) developing novel high-order numerical discretization schemes. The first challenge has led to a novel closure that has been dubbed the H^T_N closure, which hybridizes two classes of techniques: spherical harmonics and discrete ordinates. The second challenge has led the PI and collaborators to develop Chebyshev spectral methods in conjunction with the Radon transform, an approach that had not previously been considered for linear kinetic models.

* Development of novel high-order discontinuous Galerkin schemes for thin-film flows: Moment-closure approaches that reduce higher-dimensional fluid models to lower dimension "thin-film" models can result in nonlinear partial differential equations with terms that have a high number of spatial derivatives. These equations are extremely stiff and difficult to handle computationally. In this work, the PI and collaborators developed a novel approach for solving such thin-film equations using a Newton-free Picard iteration technique.

* Development of energy-stable continuous Galerkin schemes with adaptive mesh refinement for the Cahn-Hilliard Navier-Stokes model of multiphase flows: Understanding the fundamental mechanisms of phase interactions is critical to developing accurate and efficient models of two-phase flows. Such models arise in many applications (e.g., chemical/biological reactors, bio-microfluidics, and manufacturing), and can be modeled efficiently using Cahn-Hilliard Navier-Stokes (CHNS) phase-field models. The PI, students, and collaborators developed novel energy-stable numerical methods for solving the Cahn-Hilliard Navier-Stokes system. This work involved numerical method development, in-depth theoretical analysis of the resulting schemes, implementation of these methods into software, and the utilization of high-performance computing techniques, including parallelization and adaptive mesh-refinement.

The research efforts involved the training of several PhD students. The work of the PI and the associated PhD students resulted in computer codes that have been made publicly available. One of the purposes of this is to allow the research findings to be disseminated more directly than through journal publications. The resulting codes are written in C++ (for the main part of the code) and Python (for visualization). These codes are freely available on the web (http://www.dogpack-code.org) through a BSD 2-Clause License from the Open Source Initiative. The actual code is stored as a Git repository through the bitbucket.org website: https://bitbucket.org/imsejae/dogpack. These codes have been used both for research and teaching purposes and continue to be updated, improved, and expanded.
